Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: Senior OpenAI leaders, including Mr. Sutskever, who is deeply concerned that A.I. could one day destroy humanity, later discussed whether Ms. Toner should be removed, a person involved in the conversations said.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: a person involved in the conversations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: But shortly after those discussions, Mr. Sutskever did the unexpected: He sided with board members to oust Mr. Altman, according to two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: That scientist and other researchers went to the board to try to push Mr. Altman out. After they failed, they gave up and departed, according to three people familiar with the attempt to push Mr. Altman out.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: After vetting four candidates for one position, the remaining directors couldn’t agree on who should fill it, said the two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: two people familiar with the board’s deliberations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: Hours after Mr. Altman was ousted, OpenAI executives confronted the remaining board members during a video call, according to three people who were on the call.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: three people who were on the call

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: On Sunday, Mr. Sutskever was urged at OpenAI’s office to reverse course by Mr. Brockman’s wife, Anna, according to two people familiar with the exchange.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: A few weeks before Mr. Altman’s firing, he met with Ms. Toner to discuss a paper she had co-written for the Georgetown center.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Document Sources.Source Justification: a paper she had co-written for the Georgetown center

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: In the email, Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “After a series of reasonably amicable negotiations, the co-founders of Anthropic were able to negotiate their exit on mutually agreeable terms,” an Anthropic spokeswoman, Sally Aldous, said.
“I deeply regret my participation in the board’s actions.”
Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Jason Kwon, OpenAI’s chief strategy officer, said the board was endangering the future of the company by pushing out Mr. Altman.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Anthropic added that there was “no attempt to ‘oust’ Sam Altman at the time the founders of Anthropic left OpenAI.”
